dt: {bc}an excavation {dx_def}see {dxt|excavation||2}{/dx_def} for burial of a body

dt.t: believes there is life beyond the {wi}grave{/wi}

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}græf{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}grab{/it} grave, Old English {it}grafan{/it} to dig
shortdef: an excavation for burial of a body; broadly : a burial place

dt: {bc}likely to produce great harm or danger
{bc}having a serious and dignified quality or {d_link|demeanor|demeanor}
{bc}of the variety indicated by a grave accent

pt: {sc}serious{/sc} {sc}grave{/sc} {sc}solemn{/sc} {sc}sedate{/sc} {sc}staid{/sc} {sc}sober{/sc} {sc}earnest{/sc} mean not light or frivolous. {sc}serious{/sc} implies a concern for what really matters.
{sc}grave{/sc} implies both seriousness and dignity in expression or attitude.

pt.t: read the proclamation in a {it}grave{/it} voice

pt: {sc}solemn{/sc} suggests an impressive gravity utterly free from levity.
{sc}sedate{/sc} implies a composed and decorous seriousness.
{sc}staid{/sc} suggests a settled, accustomed sedateness and prim self-restraint.
{sc}sober{/sc} stresses seriousness of purpose and absence of levity or frivolity.

pt.t: a {it}sober{/it} look at the state of our schools

pt: {sc}earnest{/sc} suggests sincerity or often zealousness of purpose.

et: Middle French, from Latin {it}gravis{/it} heavy, grave {ma}{mat|grieve|}{/ma}
shortdef: likely to produce great harm or danger

dt: {bc}a grave accent ` used to show that a vowel is pronounced with a fall of pitch (as in ancient Greek), that a vowel has a certain quality (such as {it}è{/it} in French), that a final {it}e{/it} is stressed and close and that a final {it}o{/it} is stressed and low (as in Italian), that a syllable has a degree of stress between maximum and minimum (as in phonetic transcription), or that the {it}e{/it} of the English ending {it}-ed{/it} is to be pronounced (as in "this cursèd day")

shortdef: a grave accent ` used to show that a vowel is pronounced with a fall of pitch (as in ancient Greek), that a vowel has a certain quality (such as è in French), that a final e is stressed and close and that a final o is stressed and low (as in Italian), that a syllable has a degree of stress between maximum and minimum (as in phonetic transcription), or that the e of the English ending -ed is to be pronounced (as in "this cursèd day")

dt: used as a direction in music

shortdef: slowly and solemnly —used as a direction in music

dt: {bc}to carve or cut (something, such as letters or figures) into a hard surface {bc}{sx|engrave||}

dt.t: {it}graved{/it} the dates of his birth and death on the headstone

dt: {bc}to carve or shape with a chisel {bc}{sx|sculpture||}
{bc}to impress or fix (a thought, a memory, etc.) deeply

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}grafan{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}graban{/it} to dig, Old Church Slavonic po{it}greti{/it} to bury
shortdef: to carve or cut (something, such as letters or figures) into a hard surface : engrave
to carve or shape with a chisel : sculpture
to impress or fix (a thought, a memory, etc.) deeply
to clean and pay with pitch

dt: {bc}a person who digs up a buried body to steal the things that were buried with it

shortdef: a person who digs up a buried body to steal the things that were buried with it

dt.t: She was rescued from {it}a watery grave{/it}.
He believes that there is life {it}beyond the grave{/it}.

dt: {bc}to behave in a way that will cause one to lose or fail

dt.t: The coach {it}dug his own grave{/it} when he publicly insulted the team's owner.

shortdef: to behave in a way that will cause one to lose or fail
